awd_titl_txt: Few Body Dynamics of Atomic and Molecular Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the breakup of atoms and molecules remains a formidable task.  Complex experiments using free electron lasers at SLAC in California and at DESY in Germany, or low energy antiproton beams at CERN in Switzerland, are a challenge to explain for modern theoretical methods using massively parallel supercomputers.  Our project will provide new insights into the quantal dynamics found in the photon electron, and antiproton ionization of atoms like He, Li, and Mg, as well as molecules like H2 and Li2.
 
Since atomic and molecular processes are present in most physical phenomena, ranging from astronomical observations of the early universe to laboratory production of microchips a more complete understanding of the few body dynamics of atoms and molecules can lead to a wealth of new scientific discoveries.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Computational methods are applied to a wide variety of atomic

and molecular collision processes in support of a better understanding

of the astrophysical and laboratory sciences.  Current activities

include the calculation of laser interactions with atoms and molecules,

the dynamics of cold atomic and molecular gases, antiproton collisions

with atoms and molecules at low energies, and the ionization of atoms

due to collisions with bare charged atomic ions, neutrons, and

possible weakly interacting massive particles.

 

Example papers:

Five-Photon Double Ionization of Helium,

Y. Li, M. S. Pindzola, and J. Colgan,

Journal of Physics B 49 055401 (2016)

A time-dependent close-coupling method is used to calculate the

five-photon double ionization of He.  It is found that the

generalized cross section used in the past for two-photon double

ionization of He cannot be extended to five-photon double

ionization of He.  Therefore only five-photon double ionization

probabilities that depend on specfic radiation field pulses can

be calculated.

 

Multiphoton Double Ionization of Helium

using Femtosecond Laser Pulses,

M. S. Pindzola, Y. Li, and J. Colgan,

Journal of Physics B (accepted)

A time-dependent close-coupling method is used to calculate the

multiphoton double ionization of He using femtosecond laser pulses.

Total double ionization probabilities are caclulated for 2,3,4,and 5

photon absorption in the energy range from 10 eV to 60 eV.  Single

and triple differential probabilities are calculated for 2,3,4, and 5

photon absorption at energies where the total ionization probability

is near a maximum.  For circular polarization the total and differential

probabilities are consistently smaller compared to linear polarization

as the number of photons absorbed is increased while keeping the

radiation field constant.  For linear polarization, the

total and differential probabilities vary substantially as a function

of photons absorbed due to the presence of more absorption pathways.


Last Modified: 09/08/2016
Modified by: Michael S Pindzola
